description: Originally from Scots and Northern English dialects (as a verb), probably of Old Norse origin; ultimately imitative.

entries.meaning: (Scotland, Northern England) A shrill sound, as of bagpipes.
examples: To a resounding wail headed by the King-Kong skirl, all gangs joined in hauling in the net.

verbs.description: skirl (third-person singular simple present skirls, present participle skirling, simple past and past participle skirled)

entries.meaning: (Scotland, Northern England) To make a shrill sound, as of bagpipes.
examples: Come here, or stay where ye are, and skirl as loud ye can — it's a' ye're gude for — l say, ye auld deevil, skirl — skirl — louder — louder, woman — gar the gentles hear ye in the ha' — I have heard ye as far off as the Bass for a less matter.
